questions.question: 1. What does push operation on a stack do?

answers.a: Adds an element to the bottom of the stack.
answers.b: Adds an element to the top of the stack.
answers.c: Removes an element from the top of the stack.
answers.d: Adds an element in the middle of the stack.

questions.question: 2. Situation: A teacher wants to remember the names of all students in the class. Which of the following is the best possible way to use the linked list in this situation?

answers.b: Teacher asks her favorite student to memorize all others names and help her whenever needed.
answers.c: Teacher asks each student to remember the person sitting next to him/her and the teacher will only have to remember the  first person's name.
answers.d: Teacher asks all students to memorize every other student's name.

questions.question: 3. Situation: A teacher wants to remember the names of all students in the class. In the aforementioned question, what are the pros and cons of using a linked list faced by the teacher?

answers.b: To access a student's name it will take a lot of time.

questions.question: 4. Which of the following best describes a stack?

answers.d: Set of dinner plates placed on top of each other

explanations.a: People standing at starbucks would be waiting in line, the first in line would be the first to get their coffee. This is an example of a queue hence the wrong answer.
explanations.b: A family tree keeps diverging creating branches at every generation, forming a typical example of tree data structure, and hence wrong.
explanations.c: A football team is just a collection of players with no specific intentions in mind. Hence they would be classified into an array or a list which makes for a collection of items. And hence is the wrong answer.
explanations.d: To add to the plates we can only put the plate on the top, and to take on the plate, we can only still take from the top. Hence this is a classic example of Last in First Out (LIFO), a Stack and is also the correct answer

questions.question: 5. On what principle are objects inserted and removed in stacks?
